>So said Tung Wai Yip on 4/7/2003 --------------------

>Can you explain w=
hy is 1. better?

1. The data is in the test where I can see it, rather tha=
n in a file.
2. Using data in a file means worrying about where the files a=
re on the file system when executing the tests.
3. What if I need to execut=
e the tests on a file system that doesn't understand "g:/myCsvFiles"? (Yes,=
 there are solutions, but none as easy as not having to worry about it.)
4.=
 Tests that require the file system are slower.
5. Cleaning up the file sys=
tem is asynchronous (from what I can tell) and unreliable to do in tests th=
at execute at a rate of dozens per second.

>Let say I want to test some hi=
gher granularity methods like
>
>  csv.findDuplicates()
>  csv.convertToXML=
()
>  csv.calcStatistics()
>
>how would you propose to do it without readin=
g a CSV file?

Processing the data is separate from reading/writing the dat=
a. This implies two separate classes.

csvDataProcessor.findDuplicates(new =
CsvFileReader(fileName));
...

This is exactly how XSL transformers work: t=
ransforming XML and reading/writing XML are separate concerns.

Take care.
